Prompt: Rain drop size distribution model for Indian climate
Generated Text:
Rain drop size distribution model for Indian climate – An overview
Abstract
The distribution and size of rain drop can be used to estimate the rainfall intensity and its associated hazards. This paper provides an overview of the current research status and future prospects of research on raingauge size and rainfall distribution modelling in the Indian region. In the first part of this paper, rainfall and raindrop distribution models are reviewed and their limitations are discussed. The second part deals with the raintable modelling, the most commonly used model in Indian weather forecasting, and the third part discusses the use of rainting to predict the associated rainfall, its intensity as well as its hazards using rainet. Finally, some recommendations are made and directions of future research are pointed out.

Prompt: Climate profile of India
Generated Text:
Climate profile of India
In India, the climate ranges in type from equatorial in the south-west and west to arctic in its north-east, with the exception of Kashmir, which lies at the edge of the Himalayas.
The monsoon season in India extends from mid-June to mid–September and brings heavy rains over most of northern and central India. The heaviest monsoons are recorded along the West coast in Kerala, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. In the north the monseasons are drier, but are also accompanied by cyclones, thunderstorms and dust clouds, particularly in Rajasthan and Gujarat. Temperatures are high during the winter (December-February) in most parts of North India but can fall to sub –zero degrees Celsius along much of its northern border with Tibet. Summer -like conditions prevail for much longer in South India where the temperature remains in an uncomfortable range for most months.

Prompt: Possible impacts of Indian Ocean dipole mode events on global climate
Generated Text:
Possible impacts of Indian Ocean dipole mode events on global climate variability: A review
The Indian–Ocean Dipole is a natural phenomenon occurring in the Indian and Pacific oceans and its impacts on tropical climate and weather have been the subject of much scrutiny. This phenomenon is characterised by an alternation of warm and cool conditions in both the northern and southern oceans which can have significant impacts in other climatic regions of the planet. The dipoles are thought to have a strong link to the El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and are therefore often used as a proxy for the strength of tropical ENSO activity. It is important to understand the impact that IOD events have on climate as it is believed that these events can influence global surface temperatures for up to several years following the original events. In this review, we summarise the most recent research on the IMD and attempt to quantify the impacts that this event can cause on different atmospheric and oceanic phenomena.

Prompt: Indian agriculture and climate sensitivity
Generated Text:
Indian agriculture and climate sensitivity : an empirical approach
The purpose of this paper is to study the impact of climate change on the agricultural sector of India by estimating the relationship between rainfall and its components. We use an error correction and cointegration methodology to identify the long-term equilibrium relationship for the variables and also to check the existence of a long run relationship. The empirical results indicate that rainfall is a leading indicator of agricultural activity in India. This implies that agricultural development in the country is highly dependent on rainfall variability. Our analysis also indicates that India’s agricultural economy is not very climate sensitive. In this case, climate is an input for production of food in agriculture rather than being a major factor for determining its productivity. Thus, the impacts of projected climate changes would have little direct effect on agricultural production.

This research project aimed at analysing current state, vulnerability, adaptive capacity and potential mitigation for the Indian agricultural sector in the context of climate variability and change, and at identifying potential policy options to enhance adaptation capacity to climate impacts and to support climate policy development. It involved an assessment of recent climate scenarios and of possible climate changes in India; a study of current and projected impacts of climatic changes for different crops in terms of production, yield variability, market prices, labour requirements, water requirements and irrigation water use; an identification of adaptation strategies for crop production in different regions and agro-ecologies; and a cost-benefit analysis of selected adaptation measures with respect to their impact on productivity, food price and food security. In addition, a review of Indian and international policies and institutional arrangements for adaptation, mitigation and technology development was carried out to identify potential barriers and constraints in developing and implementing adaptation policies.

For the conventional system, 20 and 30% of energy savings are obtained for winter and summer conditions respectively. Prompt: Future climate change: Implications for Indian summer monsoon and its variability
Generated Text:
Future climate change: Implications for Indian summer monsoon and its variability
Abstract
The current study examines future climatic trends in the summer Indian monsoons. The study is carried out by using a coupled general circulation model (GCM) with the atmospheric component driven by a 20 year control 1961-80 simulation. Two scenarios of future climate have been considered in this study, the first scenario represents an idealistic scenario and the second represents a realistic scenario. It is observed that in both scenarios the Indian Summer Monsoon will be affected. However, there is considerable difference in their intensity, and their impacts. Under the ideal scenario, both the intensity and frequency of the mon Soons decrease. Whereas, under the realistic scenarios, intensity of summer rainfall is predicted to increase and monSoons will become more frequent and intense. These findings indicate that the changes in summer climate will result in changes to the seasonal mon soons, leading to a significant impact on agriculture, water resources management, energy demand and supply and other human activities in Asia.

We construct a monthly time series of temperature, precipitation and the fraction of the annual monsoonal rainfall occurring in April and May — the key climatic shocks affecting crop production in a region where 40% of India’s population depends on agriculture for livelihood. We find that climate shock events have become more frequent and longer in length. However, their impact on agricultural production has become less severe in recent decades due to adaptation.

Sensitivity of grain yields to historical climate variability in India.
- Publication Type:
-, 1, 3),. (2014)
Abstract
We assess the sensitivity of winter wheat yields in the Indian monsoon to past variations in temperature, precipitation and radiation in a historical climatology over India 1871-2011. We find that wheat has been more sensitive to temperature than moisture over the majority of the country, particularly in south-western regions. The sensitivity to moisture has become more important in recent years, with precipitation becoming the main driver of yields. Over the north-east wheat production is more influenced by precipitation, whereas over southwestern India the most important factor is temperature. In the future, we find a decrease for the wheat yield in all regions, and this decline is particularly large for south west India, where wheat is currently most vulnerable to climate change.

Constructions of climate justice in German, Indian and US media
Abstract
The article explores the ways in which climate injustice is constructed in the German mainstream media and the international press in a comparative perspective. The German and International press coverage of the UN Climate Conference in Copenhagen 2009 is analysed. A discourse network analysis is undertaken to identify discursive constructions of justice and injustices. Findings of an in-depth textual analysis show that climate change is framed in nationalistic discourses. Climate justice is discursively constructed as a moral and political problem of ‘global justice’ and as the need of a “green” global economic transformation. This analysis shows that the construction of injustice depends on a national and local media discourse.

Indian summer monsoon in future climate projection by a super high-resolution global model.
Abstract
A super-high resolution model of the global ocean and atmosphere is used to investigate a possible future Indian summer rainy season in the Indian monsoonal region. A global climate model is forced by the coupled atmospheric model and the ocean component with the Hadley Centre ocean model for a 20-year control simulation and a further 25 years, starting in 2020. The control run represents a climate without any anthropogenic influence. In the future experiment, the model reproduces most of features of current climate including the summer rainfall maximum over South Asia as well as the southwards shift of monolithic summer rain band and its weakening and southward shifting. However, in this future scenario the monolith is replaced with two rain bands. This leads to the weakening of summer precipitation over the western India.

Prompt: Climate change and uncertainty from 'above'and 'below': perspectives from India
Generated Text:
Climate change and uncertainty from 'above'and 'below': perspectives from India
Abstract
The impacts of climate change on human societies have been studied extensively over the last decades. Climate change research has focused mainly on impacts from the direct effects of the changes in the global climate. However, climate changes affect human society in many more ways. These impacts are caused by the complex interplay between changes that occur in nature (such as temperature and precipitation) and changes caused in society, such as changes to agriculture patterns in response to changes of temperature, changes associated with water supply, energy demands and other factors that impact our daily lives. The interactions between these ‘above’and’ ’below’ factors can lead to the amplification and/or attenuation of a given climate signal, resulting in changes above and below what might be observed for a particular climate perturbation. It is this phenomenon that makes the impact of changing climate on our human systems difficult to predict.

Prompt: The globally invasive small Indian mongoose Urva auropunctata is likely to spread with climate change
Generated Text:
The globally invasive small Indian mongoose Urva auropunctata is likely to spread with climate change. We used a model of the global dispersal of mammals to estimate the impact of climate warming on the spread of this species. Our results show that the species is unlikely to expand outside its range unless the climate warms by at least 2.3oC. Climate warming beyond these values would cause the mongose to reach areas with suitable temperature but the lack of suitable prey would limit its expansion further. This is the first time a species has been assessed for its climate suitability by combining global climate and prey species distribution data. The results suggest that climate is a better predictor of range expansion than prey availability in this invasive species, a finding that highlights the importance of considering multiple factors in the assessment of global change impact.
Introduction
The global distribution of species and the processes that control the extent of their range are key questions to address in order to understand the potential impact that global warming might have on species

Abstract. The Indian ocean dipole (IOD) is a natural, long-lived mode of variability in the coupled ocean-atmosphere circulation of a region extending from the Bay of Bengal in South-East Asia through the Western Pacific to the East Coast of Africa. In the past, it has been identified as an important climate driver, with impacts on the interannual climate variability and extreme weather events in both the Northern and the Southern Hemisphere.

Prompt: Do women on boards influence climate change disclosures to CDP?evidence from large Indian companies

Do women on boards influence climate change disclosures to CDP?evidence from large Indian companies
The study analyses the impact of female director presence on the reporting practices on climate related risks, in order to determine whether gender diversity on company board is associated with climate disclosure quality. The sample includes 1,600 companies from the Global 500 index. We employ a difference-in-difference (DiD) approach to examine the effects of having one or two women directors, on CDPR disclosure. Results indicate a reduction in carbon disclosures from companies with a single woman director, compared to those with two woman directors. These findings are consistent with the CDS theory and support the hypothesis that a higher representation of women at the boards may result in higher reporting quality of CDPs.

Prompt: ENSO, IOD and Indian Summer Monsoon in NCEP climate forecast system
Generated Text:
ENSO, IOD and Indian Summer Monsoon in NCEP climate forecast system
Abstract
This paper investigates the role of El Niño (EN) and the Indian-summer monsoon on the North American summer monsoonal circulation using the Nucleus for European Modeling of the Ocean–Atmosphere–Land System 1/4 degree climate prediction system. The model was run with and without ENSO and Iod. In addition, the IDA model with ESDM forcing was used as controls. A strong IDO is found to be a necessary component for summer rainfall in the US Midwest and central United States. This summer IENO-driven circulation is characterized by the northward displacement of low pressure systems and westward intensification of high pressure. It also results in more northwesterly winds and stronger southward winds in mid-latitudes than the control run. However, a weak EEN + IES circulation pattern can be identified in July 2015 in our model.

Prompt: Manufacturing productivity in Indian states: does investment climate matter?
Generated Text:
Manufacturing productivity in Indian states: does investment climate matter?
Abstract:The paper examines the effects of investment and other factors on manufacturing labour productivity using panel and panel-econometric methods, based on data collected for the 1992-1993 period. We estimate the effect of manufacturing investment using the method of least squares and the instrumental variable methods. The panel data method estimates an aggregate production function for manufacturing. Our results show that investment has a significant effect on productivity for Indian manufacturing firms. This implies that there is room for investment to increase productivity of the manufacturing sector in India, provided the government and local authorities do their part to encourage investment in this sector.

Prompt: A 13C record of late Quaternary climate change from tropical peats in southern India
Generated Text:
A 13C record of late Quaternary climate change from tropical peats in southern India: Evidence for the impact of the Indo-Pacific Warm Pool
Abstract
We present (13)C data of peat-forming plant biomass from the western ghats of southern peninsular India, and the results of a numerical model for carbon isotope composition. We interpret the data in the context of changes in precipitation and temperature, based on the 18O and 17O records. During the last glacial cycle (~ 20 kyears), the southward expansion of cold air from northern mid-latitudes led to the formation of an ice sheet over northern India. The resulting climate amelioration was followed by a shift in monsoon rainfall to more southern latitudes. This resulted in higher rainfall over the southern ghat region, but with a pronounced shift to earlier and drier monsoons, which were probably related to a change in sea surface temperature - in particular, the warming of tropical waters.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact and future impact on health due to climate variability and extreme weather in the state of Assam, India. In order to assess the vulnerability of population to the climate changes, it has been studied the impacts of heatwaves and rainfall variability on morbidity and mortality during the last five years 2011-2015. We have analyzed the association of temperature, precipitation, and heatwave with the death due cardiovascular disease, diarrheal and respiratory tract infections. Our results indicated that extreme climatic events like heatstroke and floods in this area is a threat to health, with an increased risk of morbidity in vulnerable groups and increased mortality in elderly people. Further, we found that climate related diseases like diarrhoeal infections are the major causes of death in Assam during summer months and the main factors for the rise of diarrhetic diseases are temperature and humidity.

Prompt: Actors, objectives, context: A framework of the political economy of energy and climate policy applied to India, Indonesia, and Vietnam
Generated Text:
Actors, objectives, context: A framework of the political economy of energy and climate policy applied to India, Indonesia, and Vietnam
- 6 Downloads
Abstract
We explore a framework for political economists to explain the design and implementation of policies on energy, the environment, climate change, renewable energy technologies and energy access, focusing on the three largest energy users in South-East Asia, India (1 billion people), Indonesia (~260 million), and Viet Nam (>90 million). Our framework has three levels. At the first, or macro level, we explore the role and influence of actors who seek to influence the policy agenda, their strategies, goals and resources. The micro level concerns the objectives of policy – what is being achieved or sought to be achieved. It includes issues of efficiency and equity, as well as environmental impacts. Finally, policy is situated in particular contexts. We focus on how the macro and micro levels interact to produce a political-economic framework, which we apply to the energy issues in India.
KeywordsEnergy Climate Change Climate policy India Indonesia Renewable energy Vietnam Energy access

Prompt: Climatic oscillations and tuna catch rates in the Indian Ocean: a wavelet approach to time series analysis
Generated Text:
Climatic oscillations and tuna catch rates in the Indian Ocean: a wavelet approach to time series analysis
Abstract: This paper presents a study on the relationship between the climatic oscillation and the fishery catch rate in a sub-tropical region, which has a strong influence in tuna fisher. The study used the time-frequency technique and wavelets transform to analyse tuna landings time -series of the western Indian ocean, from 1972 to 2001. Using the wave-let analysis, two dominant modes were extracted from the data. From the first mode, the annual cycle is identified; and from second mode the monthly cycle and subannual cycle are identified, and are found to be the dominant oscillators. Then, an autocorrelation analysis was applied to the second harmonic of this oscillator. Finally, a Granger causality test is applied in order to check the causation between two series. It was shown that the fishing activity is affected by climatic conditions.
Keywords: Wavelets, Fishery data, Granger Causality,
Language: English

Generated Text:

Abstract
Cities play a critical role in global climate change impacts and adaptation. The Himalayan region is projected to be one of the most vulnerable regions, and cities are likely to bear the brunt of extreme climate events. This paper seeks to contribute to understanding of adaptation processes in Himalayan urban environments. Households living in two informal settlements in Shimla were studied to understand their adaptation strategies, decisionmaking processes, vulnerability and coping capacities. A mixed-methods approach was used to elicit information through a semi-structured questionnaire, in-depth interviews, focus group discussions and a household survey. Results indicate that adaptation to climate hazards is not yet well understood, though some households have been able to identify and implement adaptation responses. Vulnerability and capacity analyses were conducted to assess the vulnerability to and the coping capacity of households and community groups. These analyses indicated that the capacity for households to cope with climate-change impacts is affected by gender, education level, income level and household size.

Abstract. Chromolaenia odorate is a non-native tree introduced to the region as a commercial timber source. It is now a major threat to forests and agricultural fields of South and Southeast Asia and has the potential to cause major economic losses in these regions. To determine the current and future range of the invasive tree under the scenario of projected temperature and precipitation changes, a GIS-based approach has been used to predict the future geographical range. The current distribution data were collected from literature and GIS. In this study, we have considered three possible future climate scenarios. Our aim was to assess the suitability of different climatic scenarios by considering the species’ distribution. The Atlantic Multidecade Oscillation – AMO has long been hypothesized to be a driver or a modulator of the tropical atmospheric circulations. Here, we assess the role of this mode of climate variability in the summer Indian monsoonal rainfall. To assess this, our climate simulations include the AMOs and a control simulation with a prescribed AMOSc amplitude and no other climate forcing. The climate simulation is performed with the climate component Bergen model. We compare the simulated tropical climate to a multi-model ensemble of simulations performed by the CMIP6 models, which includes both the observed AMOC and AMOV, and to the historical climate.
